slideInfo.title: What is the meaning and significance of the painting?

pButton.Name: A
pButton.popInfo: The left side of the painting takes place on Shrove Tuesday, the last day before Lent and represents the activities of Carnival. “Shrove” comes from the phrase “to shrive” or to hear confessions. In Mardi Gras celebrations, this day is known as “fat Tuesday.”

pButton.Name: B
pButton.popInfo: The activity on the right side of the painting takes place on Ash Wednesday and represents the activities of Lent.

pButton.Name: C
pButton.popInfo: A line of lepers led by a bagpiper parade past an inn begging for bread.

pButton.Name: D
pButton.popInfo: Soberly dressed people file into church to get blessed.

pButton.Name: E
pButton.popInfo: A bawdy popular play is performed in an impromptu tent as the people drinking in an inn lean out the windows to watch.

pButton.Name: F
pButton.popInfo: Crippled beggars congregate but are mostly ignored.

pButton.Name: G
pButton.popInfo: Women prepare fish for Lent near the town well.

pButton.Name: H
pButton.popInfo: Nuns and townsfolk give alms, or charity in the form of money or goods given to the needy, and help to the poor and crippled.

pButton.Name: I
pButton.popInfo: Costumed merrymakers play music and others gamble at cards and dice.
